text: If something has changed since then
column4: I am not aware. Either way we need some accountability on why India's annual crime stats are so late.

text: When I asked in August if there were newly published crime categories that were delaying the publication
column4: I was told there were not.

text: The report usually comes out in June or July. The last time it was this late was seven years ago.
So what we're waiting for at the end of October 2017 is the official crime statistics for calendar year 2016.
This is the National Crime Records Bureau's Crime in India report. The NCRB is under the union Home Ministry.
I'm on long leave but just wanted to flag something - India's​ annual crime statistics are highly delayed this year.

text: @lavsmohan @thenewsminute How completely super and super-needed!
Just thought this is something lawyers and those interested in women's access to justice might want to brainstorm about a bit. Thanks (ends)
We have a serious legal gap for anyone who isn't reporting crime immediately
column4: and for child sexual abuse that is often impossible.

text: If these cases got to court
column4: they would come up against the "why the delay" q. But it is appalling that they cannot even make it to court.

text: So here we are
column4: where a woman who wants to report rape (by today's definitions) that took place 5 years cannot find a single applicable law.

text: Where the statute of limitations does kick in is for IPC 354 (molestation) prior to 2013.
Additionally
column4: the definition of rape was broadened only by the 2013 amendment to 376
column5: so those changes do not apply retrospectively either.

text: This despite the fact that the statute of limitations does not apply to POCSO.
Since POCSO was passed only in 2012 and does not apply retrospectively
column4: a woman today reporting abuse even five years ago is stuck.

text: For reference
column4: this is the story
column5: of a woman wondering how to access justice for a crime from her childhood https://t.co/em2SmL5RF4
